column1: Statement:ID
Charterers or their agents shall have the option of cancelling this Charter.
The proper construction of this particular charterparty is
column2: as I see it
column3: as follows. The obligation regarding bunkers on delivery imposed by clauses 3 and 56 is
column4: if broken
column5: readily capable of giving rise to a claim for damages. There is no reason to treat the charter as conferring in respect of it the more draconian remedy of cancellation which would apply automatically if its performance was directly relevant under clause 14. Properly understood
column6: clause 14 operates by reference to lines 34 to 45. If the vessel on tender for delivery lacked bunkers
column7: to an extent which meant that she did not comply with some aspect of lines 34 to 45
column8: cancellation under clause 14 would become a possibility. In that context
column9: the question whether the deficiency was of real commercial significance could arise. In the present case
column10: charterers' only contention before the arbitrator was that mere non-compliance with clauses 3 and 56 automatically entitled them to cancel. They did not seek to justify their cancellation with reference to lines 34 to 45 at all. The award contains nothing to enable them to do so now
column11: and there is no basis for remission.

column1: 11. There are two additional facts that are relevant. The first is that the On-Hire Surveyor certified that bunkering was complete at 1400 hours on the 10th when 722 tonnes of HFO
column2: 89 tonnes of IFO and 107 tonnes of MDO were on board. The second is that it was alleged .... and not denied
column3: that from the physical point of view the vessel was ready to sail at 1000 hours.

column1: It does not assist charterers to argue that
column2: if they had identified a place for delivery
column3: owners would not have delivered the vessel in time and in the right condition at that place. The operation of the cancelling clause depends on delivery actually being due and not being made when due. Charterers' contention that they were under no obligation to select the place for delivery
column4: since it was clear that owners would not be able to deliver in the right condition and in time at any place so selected
column5: has no basis. In practical terms
column6: it would lead after the event to speculative arguments whether charterers were right about this. In principle
column7: there is no way in which charterers were relieved of their obligation to identify the place for delivery
column8: merely because they considered
column9: however correctly
column10: that owners would be unable to effect delivery there by the time specified in the cancelling clause. It was not suggested that any inability in fact to deliver there by that time with the agreed bunkers (or any indication that there may have been of any intention to deliver there by that time without the agreed bunkers) involved any breach of charter
column11: still less a breach of condition or repudiation by owners which
column13: could have relieved charterers from further performance. The effect of the cancelling clause was simply that charterers would have a right to cancel
column14: and owners would be vulnerable to loss of the charter
column17: due delivery was not made by the time specified in the clause. Costs of any steps taken to effect an abortive tender (if delivery is tendered late and charterers cancel) fall on owners
column18: not on charterers. In the present case
column19: charterers' failure to identify any place for delivery means in my judgment that delivery never became due at all
column20: and charterers' claim to invoke the cancellation clause was unjustified.

column1: of the quantities specified in clause 56 would not justify cancellation
column2: especially since clause 56 requires the vessel to be redelivered with approx. same quantities as on redelivery and calls for settlement of any differences between delivery and redelivery quantities at Platts mean price ruling on redelivery. The very fact that this difficulty would exist
column3: whether or not it could then be overcome as a matter of construction
column4: may itself be a further pointer towards the irrelevance of clauses 3 and 56 in the context of clause 14.

column1: The charterers accept that there are some provisions in the charterparty which would fall to be complied with at the time of any delivery
column2: but non-compliance with which would still not justify cancellation. As examples
column3: one may take owners' obligations to comply with the very detailed provisions regarding the vessel's description
column4: capacities and capabilities introduced by lines 1 to 25 and clause 55. Owners also refer to clauses 21 (maintenance of cargo gear)
column5: 40 (blacklisting) and 43 (safety in ballast) as potential further examples
column6: which I need not consider. Charterers
column7: as I understand it
column8: distinguish any such provisions in two ways. First
column9: they are not specifically related to delivery in the same way as the obligation under clauses 3 and 56 regarding the quantities of bunkers to be on board on delivery. Secondly
column10: they go to permanent
column11: as distinct from variable
column12: characteristics of the vessel. The first distinction has some force
column13: but in other respects clauses 3 and 56 are not so confined. Clause 3
column14: into the scheme of which clause 56 is in effect set
column15: starts by assuming that delivery has been validly effected (The Charterers on delivery .... shall take over and pay for all fuel and diesel oil remaining on board the vessel ....). Clauses 3 and 56 then provide for the quantities with which the vessel is to be delivered. Both clauses also deal with redelivery. The basis and logic of the second distinction are not obvious and it appear open to the objection that a number of the matters covered by lines 1 to 25 and clause 55 (and indeed the other clauses mentioned) would be capable of being rectified.

column1: 1951 1 K. B. 223 drew attention to the nature of a cancelling clause as a forfeiture clause
column2: which should not be applied lightly. That was in a context where the issue was on whom the onus lay to show matters relevant to its application and what the test of readiness to load was. But
column3: because the clause is a forfeiture clause
column4: caution is also appropriate in extending its application by reference to provisions of the charter outside the language of lines 34 to 45. In

column1: Roskill J. had to construe a cancelling clause
column2: clause 22
column3: in a time charter in similar language to the present. It applied should the vessel not be delivered by the 2nd day of May 1957 ..... Mr Staughton
column4: as he then was
column5: argued for owners that delivery under clause 22 imported no more than a tender of or placing or offering to place the vessel at the charterer's disposal. Roskill J. rejected the argument
column6: holding that the charter must be construed as a whole and that delivered in clause 22 related to the delivery provisions of clause 1
column7: whereby owners agreed to let and charterers to hire the vessel for three months from the time .... the Vessel is delivered and placed at the disposal of the Charterers between 9 a. m. and 6 p. m. pr between 9 a. m. and 2 p.m. if on Saturday
column8: at CALCUTTA in such available berth where she can safely lie always afloat
column9: she being in every way fitted for ordinary cargo service. Clause 22 thus provided a right of cancellation if the vessel was not
column10: when tendered for delivery
column11: in every way fitted for ordinary cargo service.

column1: the cancelling clause applied should vessel not be ready in accordance with the provisions hereof. Counsel
column2: myself as it happened
column3: argued unsuccessfully before both the tribunal and Webster J. that it should be related to all provisions of the charter applicable at the delivery date. The arbitrators disagreed (see page 380) on the basis that it was specifically related to those provisions of the charter dealing with readiness for delivery
column4: and in particular clause 3 (the parallel of lines 34 to 45 in the present charter). Webster J. also concluded that the words ready in accordance with the provisions hereof referred to readiness under clause 3 (see page 387).

column1: The conjunction of a cancelling clause and primary delivery provisions like lines 34 to 45 is natural and familiar. If the cancelling clause had been intended to relate to other specific obligations
column2: such as the obligation to have certain quantities of bunkers on board on delivery
column3: this could have been made clear. It would have been easy to include a specific reference to compliance on delivery with clauses 3 and/or 56 in either lines 34 to 45 or clause 14 itself. It may be
column4: as charterers submit
column5: that there could be advantages in terms of simplicity and certainty in such a link. On the other hand
column6: there could be objections in terms of rigidity and the expansion of the right to cancel to circumstances where the discrepancy in bunkers was of no conceivable relevance. If a vessel to be delivered under clause 14 requires bunkers complying with clauses 3 and 56
column7: I can see no scope for any qualification limiting the requirement to circumstances where the discrepancy is of real commercial significance.

column1: In support of this conclusion
column2: charterers point out that clauses 3 and 56 deal expressly with the position at the time of delivery
column3: as do lines 34 to 45 and clause 14. There is thus
column4: they submit
column5: no difficulty in treating delivery under clause 14 as meaning delivery in accordance with clauses 3 and 56 as well as lines 34 to 45. Further
column6: they submit
column7: there is good reason to do so. Read with clause 14
column8: the specific provisions of clauses 3 and 56 would obviate any arguments (which in the context of a time-charter for a vaguely defined trip could involve obvious difficulty) as to the extent of the bunkers necessary to make the vessel fit under lines 34 to 45. Clauses 3 and 56 would in effect crystallize in relation to bunkers the requirements which the vessel must satisfy if the vessel is to count as duly delivered for the purposes of the cancellation clause.

column1: In my judgment
column2: neither of charterers' arguments on the first ground is correct. The making of delivery depends under lines 34 to 45 upon charterers identifying where delivery is to take place. The only charterparty agreement is that time runs from the placing of the vessel at charterers' disposal at the place so selected by charterers. There is no basis on which even owners
column3: still less charterers when they were in default of selection
column4: can claim to treat delivery as having been made on any other basis or at any other place. It is of course the case that a time charter of this description does not import any transfer of possession (see e.g.

column1: service
column2: having water ballast and with sufficient power to operate all cargo-handling gear simultaneously (and with full complement of officers and crew for a vessel of her tonnage)
column3: her delivery could thus be rejected and the charterers could cancel. The case was not put before the arbitrator on the basis of any suggested breach of lines 34 to 45. The only relevant argument which he addresses (and which he accepted) depends on clauses 3 and 56 and was that delivery with bunkers complying with these clauses was also required to avoid exposure to cancellation under clause 14.

column1: service
column2: having water ballast and with sufficient power to operate all cargo-handling gear simultaneously (and with full complement of officers and crew for a vessel of her tonnage)
column3: her delivery could thus be rejected and the charterers could cancel. The case was not put before the arbitrator on the basis of any suggested breach of lines 34 to 45. The only relevant argument which he addresses (and which he accepted) depends on clauses 3 and 56 and was that delivery with bunkers complying with these clauses was also required to avoid exposure to cancellation under clause 14.

column1: In support of this conclusion
column2: charterers point out that clauses 3 and 56 deal expressly with the position at the time of delivery
column3: as do lines 34 to 45 and clause 14. There is thus
column4: they submit
column5: no difficulty in treating delivery under clause 14 as meaning delivery in accordance with clauses 3 and 56 as well as lines 34 to 45. Further
column6: they submit
column7: there is good reason to do so. Read with clause 14
column8: the specific provisions of clauses 3 and 56 would obviate any arguments (which in the context of a time-charter for a vaguely defined trip could involve obvious difficulty) as to the extent of the bunkers necessary to make the vessel fit under lines 34 to 45. Clauses 3 and 56 would in effect crystallize in relation to bunkers the requirements which the vessel must satisfy if the vessel is to count as duly delivered for the purposes of the cancellation clause.

column1: Although this may not itself amount to a positive finding in owners' favour

column3: if the point became material

The owners' effectively undisputed allegations were that the vessel had on board as at 1200 hours on 10th August 1995 approximately twice the quantity of fuel required to proceed to all contemplated loadports in Japan
column6: where charterers anyway intended to refuel her prior to her cross-Pacific voyage. At the end of the argument
column7: Mr Southern for the charterers conceded that no case had ever been raised before the arbitrator of lack of compliance with lines 34 to 45
column8: and that there was no basis for remission in that context.

column1: The proper construction of this particular charterparty is
column2: as I see it
column3: as follows. The obligation regarding bunkers on delivery imposed by clauses 3 and 56 is
column4: if broken
column5: readily capable of giving rise to a claim for damages. There is no reason to treat the charter as conferring in respect of it the more draconian remedy of cancellation which would apply automatically if its performance was directly relevant under clause 14. Properly understood
column6: clause 14 operates by reference to lines 34 to 45. If the vessel on tender for delivery lacked bunkers
column7: to an extent which meant that she did not comply with some aspect of lines 34 to 45
column8: cancellation under clause 14 would become a possibility. In that context
column9: the question whether the deficiency was of real commercial significance could arise. In the present case
column10: charterers' only contention before the arbitrator was that mere non-compliance with clauses 3 and 56 automatically entitled them to cancel. They did not seek to justify their cancellation with reference to lines 34 to 45 at all. The award contains nothing to enable them to do so now
column11: and there is no basis for remission.

column1: This is an appeal by leave from an arbitration award of Mr John Maskell dated 10th January 1997. It concerns the proper construction of time charterparty dated 2nd August 1995 made on the ASBATIME form
column2: with amendments
column3: between the claimant owners and the respondent charterers of m/s North Sea. Owners' claim against the charterers was for alleged wrongful cancellation of the charter. The arbitrator rejected the claim
column4: holding that charterers were entitled to cancel the charter for non-delivery by the time stipulated in the cancelling clause
column5: clause 14.

column4: capacities and capabilities introduced by lines 1 to 25 and clause 55. Owners also refer to clauses 21 (maintenance of cargo gear)

column9: they are not specifically related to delivery in the same way as the obligation under clauses 3 and 56 regarding the quantities of bunkers to be on board on delivery. Secondly

Clauses 3 and 56 then provide for the quantities with which the vessel is to be delivered. Both clauses also deal with redelivery. The basis and logic of the second distinction are not obvious and it appear open to the objection that a number of the matters covered by lines 1 to 25 and clause 55 (and indeed the other clauses mentioned) would be capable of being rectified.

column1: The conjunction of a cancelling clause and primary delivery provisions like lines 34 to 45 is natural and familiar. If the cancelling clause had been intended to relate to other specific obligations
column2: such as the obligation to have certain quantities of bunkers on board on delivery
column3: this could have been made clear. It would have been easy to include a specific reference to compliance on delivery with clauses 3 and/or 56 in either lines 34 to 45 or clause 14 itself. It may be
column4: as charterers submit
column5: that there could be advantages in terms of simplicity and certainty in such a link. On the other hand
column6: there could be objections in terms of rigidity and the expansion of the right to cancel to circumstances where the discrepancy in bunkers was of no conceivable relevance. If a vessel to be delivered under clause 14 requires bunkers complying with clauses 3 and 56
column7: I can see no scope for any qualification limiting the requirement to circumstances where the discrepancy is of real commercial significance.

column3: and the matter will be remitted to the arbitrator for him to assess damages for the charterers' breach of contract.

column1: The proper construction of this particular charterparty is
column2: as I see it
column3: as follows. The obligation regarding bunkers on delivery imposed by clauses 3 and 56 is
column4: if broken
column5: readily capable of giving rise to a claim for damages. There is no reason to treat the charter as conferring in respect of it the more draconian remedy of cancellation which would apply automatically if its performance was directly relevant under clause 14. Properly understood
column6: clause 14 operates by reference to lines 34 to 45. If the vessel on tender for delivery lacked bunkers
column7: to an extent which meant that she did not comply with some aspect of lines 34 to 45
column8: cancellation under clause 14 would become a possibility. In that context
column9: the question whether the deficiency was of real commercial significance could arise. In the present case
column10: charterers' only contention before the arbitrator was that mere non-compliance with clauses 3 and 56 automatically entitled them to cancel. They did not seek to justify their cancellation with reference to lines 34 to 45 at all. The award contains nothing to enable them to do so now
column11: and there is no basis for remission.

column7: they say

column1: In my judgment
column2: neither of charterers' arguments on the first ground is correct. The making of delivery depends under lines 34 to 45 upon charterers identifying where delivery is to take place. The only charterparty agreement is that time runs from the placing of the vessel at charterers' disposal at the place so selected by charterers. There is no basis on which even owners
column3: still less charterers when they were in default of selection
column4: can claim to treat delivery as having been made on any other basis or at any other place. It is of course the case that a time charter of this description does not import any transfer of possession (see e.g.

column2: per Roskill J. at p. 238). But the express language of lines 34 to 45 requires delivery to be effected by placing of the vessel at the charterers' disposal at a place to be selected by charterers. Unless and until charterers select such a place
column3: owners cannot deliver in accordance with the charter
column4: although they may have a claim for damages against time charterers for failure duly to select the place for delivery (see e.g.

column1: Roskill J. had to construe a cancelling clause
column2: clause 22
column3: in a time charter in similar language to the present. It applied should the vessel not be delivered by the 2nd day of May 1957 ..... Mr Staughton
column4: as he then was
column5: argued for owners that delivery under clause 22 imported no more than a tender of or placing or offering to place the vessel at the charterer's disposal. Roskill J. rejected the argument
column6: holding that the charter must be construed as a whole and that delivered in clause 22 related to the delivery provisions of clause 1
column7: whereby owners agreed to let and charterers to hire the vessel for three months from the time .... the Vessel is delivered and placed at the disposal of the Charterers between 9 a. m. and 6 p. m. pr between 9 a. m. and 2 p.m. if on Saturday
column8: at CALCUTTA in such available berth where she can safely lie always afloat
column9: she being in every way fitted for ordinary cargo service. Clause 22 thus provided a right of cancellation if the vessel was not
column10: when tendered for delivery
column11: in every way fitted for ordinary cargo service.
